image.altText: A male and a female ballet dancer strike a pose on stage

items.synopsis: After a stunning career that became the bestselling book and film, Mao's Last Dancer, the artistic director of the Queensland Ballet, Li Cunxin, has announced his plans to step away for good amid health concerns.

title.children: Mao's Last Dancer to step down after stunning career amid health concerns

image.altText: Baby Jarrod at time of second visit to Caboolture hospital in October 2022. The child has a rash around his mouth and face

items.synopsis: Baby Jarrod was in "absolute agony" when his parents took him to the emergency department two days in a row. He only received a diagnosis when his father called in Ryan's Rule.

title.children: Baby in 'absolute agony' turned away days after assurances hospital was providing best possible care

image.altText: Thorpe holds a phone up for Hargraves as he reads a message from it to journalists.

items.synopsis: Independent senator Lidia Thorpe gives her full support to the No case for the Voice to Parliament, following what she called a breakdown in negotiations with government on Indigenous justice.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe announces she will be backing No campaign against Indigenous Voice

image.altText: Red dirt barron landscape shot

items.synopsis: The 27-year-old was last seen walking away from a campsite near the remote town of Noccundra in outback Queensland in October 2021.

title.children: 'No likelihood of him being alive': Pre-inquest begins into man who went missing in outback Queensland

image.altText: Collins gestures with one hand while speaking at the despatch box in the House of Representatives.

items.synopsis: The federal government has left open the option of pursuing housing options that will be met with less resistance, after failing to pass its signature $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund.

title.children: Housing minister won't rule out dumping signature $10b fund in favour of easier paths to building housing

image.altText: A composite image of two men and a woman, separated by paper tears.

items.synopsis: Across Australia, more than 46,000 clients under state control are prevented by law from being identified, but there are growing calls for change. Some say gag laws that were designed to protect vulnerable people are shielding the agencies involved from scrutiny.

title.children: Memories sent to the tip, refused money for Christmas — and all by order of the state

image.altText: vehicles lined up next to each other with black and white logos

items.synopsis: The truck, carrying $10,000 of fresh meat, went on to damage about 30 vehicles as it was driven down the Bruce Highway. The alleged thief had also stopped by a few hardware stores to buy paint in a bid to conceal the truck's logos.

title.children: 'This blew us away, the power of social media': Online sleuths help locate butcher shop truck stolen in brazen heist

image.altText: Three people cart a green turtle on a trolley to the ocean

items.synopsis: Sick and dying turtles on the Fraser Coast will no longer have to be rushed on a three-hour drive to Australia Zoo with the opening of Hervey Bay's own turtle hospital.

title.children: New Hervey Bay turtle hospital a 'marriage of rehab, rescue, and research'

image.altText: Women in black shirt holding flyer looks sad

items.synopsis: Carrie-Ann Adams's symptoms were mistaken for the flu — but in reality, she was dying of bowel cancer and had 12 weeks to live.

title.children: Ann says lowering the bowel cancer screening age could have saved her 41yo daughter's life

image.altText: Black and white photograph of a man playing the guitar with long hair

items.synopsis: Crispin Dye's case which was due to be revisited today at an inquiry has now been delayed after a judge described NSW Police record keeping as "borderline shambolic".

title.children: New evidence about brutal death of AC/DC manager uncovered during gay hate inquiry

image.altText: A man and a woman standing in a green paddock.

items.synopsis: When the American military turned up at Ray Taylor's family farm in southern Queensland on a search for salad during WWII it launched a business that continues today.

title.children: Could you work with your family? Many generations of this family have made it work

image.altText: A woman in a hospital bed in a coma.

items.synopsis: Kylee Enwright is back in her home community after falling and hitting her head 10 hours into a Thailand holiday with her husband.

title.children: NSW woman flown home from Thailand after 'terrible' holiday accident

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: Minutes from this month's RBA board meeting show interest rates were almost kept steady this month, but it wants to slow employment and economic growth.

title.children: The Reserve Bank almost left interest rates on hold this month, but it also wants the unemployment rate to rise

image.altText: Close up of red and green numbers on ASX board

items.synopsis: The local share market rises to a fresh seven-week high, while the Australian dollar slips after the Reserve Bank releases its June meeting minutes, detailing its worries of inflation becoming entrenched in the economy.

title.children: RBA says unemployment will hit 4.5pc next year, Aussie dollar slips on interest rate meeting minutes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's largest private health insurer Medibank Private has confirmed that a file containing names and contact details of its staff members had been compromised after its building manager was targeted by a cybercriminals. Medibank said one of its property managers that uses file transfer software MOVEit faced a cyberattack, which included a file with employee names, email addresses and phone numbers. The company added that the file did not include employee bank details, payroll, or home addresses. Medibank also said its systems have not been impacted by the MOVEit cyberattack, and that it was not aware of any customers' data being compromised. Previously, in October, Medibank reported a cyber incident where the personal details of around 4 million customers was accessed by Russian cybercriminals. Over the past 10 months, Australia has been roiled by a raft of cyberattacks, prompting regulators to investigate company practices of handling personal information.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Medibank staff details stolen after building manager hacked

children.content: Australia's largest private health insurer Medibank Private has confirmed that a file containing names and contact details of its staff members had been compromised after its building manager was targeted by a cybercriminals.
Medibank said one of its property managers that uses file transfer software MOVEit faced a cyberattack, which included a file with employee names, email addresses and phone numbers.
The company added that the file did not include employee bank details, payroll, or home addresses.
Medibank also said its systems have not been impacted by the MOVEit cyberattack, and that it was not aware of any customers' data being compromised.
Previously, in October, Medibank reported a cyber incident where the personal details of around 4 million customers was accessed by Russian cybercriminals.
Over the past 10 months, Australia has been roiled by a raft of cyberattacks , prompting regulators to investigate company practices of handling personal information.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was short and sweet, but Michele Bullock has finished both her speech and Q+A session at the Ai Group event in Newcastle. There's still a bit to unpack from what she said — after all, unemployment is the one measure the RBA wants to see go up so it knows it's bringing inflation under control. If you want to go back and read her speech in full for yourself, the RBA has conveniently shared it on their site (complete with graphs, if you're into that kind of thing). My colleague Gareth Hutchens and senior business correspondent Peter Ryan were also watching her speech — you can read their report below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: That's it for the RBA deputy governor's speech

featuredLink.title: The Reserve Bank almost left interest rates on hold this month, but it also wants the unemployment rate to rise a little

children.content: It was short and sweet, but Michele Bullock has finished both her speech and Q+A session at the Ai Group event in Newcastle.
There's still a bit to unpack from what she said — after all, unemployment is the one measure the RBA wants to see go up so it knows it's bringing inflation under control.
If you want to go back and read her speech in full for yourself,
the RBA has conveniently shared it on their site
(complete with graphs, if you're into that kind of thing).
My colleague Gareth Hutchens and senior business correspondent Peter Ryan were also watching her speech — you can read their report below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA governor Philip Lowe's term is up in September, and one Newcastle councillor has asked Bullock the question she probably wasn't expecting today — would she take over in the top job? "No comment," she says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Would Michele Bullock take Philip Lowe's job?

children.content: RBA governor Philip Lowe's term is up in September, and one Newcastle councillor has asked Bullock the question she probably wasn't expecting today — would she take over in the top job?

image.altText: A small submersible plunging into the water.

items.synopsis: Deep in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean, a search is underway for a submersible that was carrying five people when it disappeared on an expedition to the wreckage of the Titanic.

title.children: Frantic search as Titanic submersible disappears underwater with five people and 96 hours' oxygen

image.altText: A male security guard stands with his back to the camera as shoppers walk past.

items.synopsis: More private security guards are patrolling public places like schools, shopping strips and libraries. Some find the trend reassuring, while others say it's alarming.

title.children: Why are Australians turning to private security guards in record numbers?

image.altText: 2023 farmer of the year Herbert profile

items.synopsis: Tess and Andrew Herbert's "excellent" and innovative business practices allowed them weather the drought, the pandemic and catastrophic flooding. Now their efforts have been recognised with a top honour.

title.children: How diversity helped 2023's Farmers of the Year keep a 150-year-old operation running strong

image.altText: A collage of black and white images of a man smiling in a suit and tie, holding a rifle, and in a passport-style photo.

items.synopsis: The untold spy story of a mole in ASIO's ranks who sold the Soviets highly classified intelligence and got away with it.

title.children: By the time Australia's spy agency learned one of its officers was a KGB mole he was retired and playing golf

image.altText: Josh makes a peace sign while wearing formal attire

items.synopsis: Cracks in the National Disability Insurance Scheme contributed to the death of a 24-year-old man who died after being handcuffed at Perth's underground train station, according to a disability advocate.

title.children: 'Josh didn't have support': Gaps in NDIS contributed to death of man at train station, disability advocate says

image.altText: A man holds a pen to sign a piece of a paper while sitting next to another man.

items.synopsis: India's IndiGo airline is buying 500 passenger jets from Airbus, in a record order that underscores surging demand in the country.

title.children: Indian airline IndiGo orders 500 Airbus jets to set new record

image.altText: Three people stand in blizzard at Mount Hotham.

items.synopsis: A polar air mass sends the mercury plunging over south-eastern Australia on Tuesday and Wednesday, while a thick rain band is brewing in the north-west and set to deliver falls across the country by the end of the week.

title.children: 'Unusually' timed tropical rainfall to feed rain across the country, as polar air mass plunges temperatures in the east

image.altText: A grey card with the PTV and myki symbols is placed against a card reader which says the card has expired.

items.synopsis: Another company which lost the contract to provide Victoria's public transport ticketing system has called for an urgent review of the tender process, saying it lacked rigour and transparency.

title.children: 'Mistakes have clearly been made': Second letter from failed bidder urges review of Victoria's myki overhaul contract

image.altText: Putin says he may seize 'buffer zone' in Ukraine

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin has a brutal new strategy to ensure Russia's invasion of Ukraine is "a long process". It means there are now strategic and humanitarian imperatives for the West to defeat Putin's latest theory of victory, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Vladimir Putin's plan to win quickly in Ukraine failed. Russia is now implementing an even more brutal strategy

image.altText: Steve Smith rolls on the ground

items.synopsis: England started day four of the first Ashes Test with a wild reverse ramp from Joe Root, and never looked back on a thrilling day of Test cricket. Here's the five things you missed overnight.

title.children: Five quick hits — Root's unorthodox batting raises eyebrows and Bairstow lets Khawaja off

image.altText: An empty synthetic turf field.

items.synopsis: The number of artificial turf sports fields in NSW has increased from 30 in 2018 to 181 at last count, concerning community groups about their potential environmental impact.

title.children: The EU has banned synthetic turf that uses old tyres. Why isn't Australia following suit?

image.altText: A trial field of cannabis growing in Queensland.

items.synopsis: The Legalise Cannabis party says the move to reform cannabis legislation will help shift Australians out of the criminal justice system.

title.children: Bills to be introduced in three states to legalise cannabis for personal use

image.altText: A sign post with pathways saying Yes and No against a blue sky

items.synopsis: For the first time in 24 years, Australians are heading to the polls to decide on a change to the constitution. Legislation setting up a referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament passed the Senate on Monday, meaning a referendum has to be held before the end of the year.

title.children: It's official — the Voice referendum is happening. Here's what comes next

image.altText: Aerial shot lookingn straight down at big battery project under construction

items.synopsis: One of the world's biggest renewable energy providers is increasing its stakes in Australia after receiving approval to build a multi-billion-dollar battery in Western Australia's coal heartlands.

title.children: French green energy giant doubles down on Australia with mega WA battery

image.altText: A man in a suit is pictured walking holding his phone up to his ear, he is surrounded by big grey buildings in Beijing CBD.

items.synopsis: From cutting salaries and bonuses and asking staff not to wear expensive clothes and watches at work, to reining in travel and entertainment expenses, Chinese financial firms have jumped on an austerity drive as Beijing pushes to bridge the wealth gap.

title.children: No more flashy clothes, designer bags or five-star hotels: Chinese bankers told to rein in expenses in austerity drive

image.altText: Greig Pickhaver aka HG Nelson wearing a navy blue collared shirt and smiling at David Wenham, who's sitting opposite him

items.synopsis: He's one half of much-loved comedy duo Roy and HG, but Greig Pickhaver says a diagnosis of dyslexia was both a "blessing and a curse" as he carved out a successful career "making up things on the spot".

title.children: Greig 'HG Nelson' Pickhaver on why planning out life is 'a complete crock'
